root.title: Modern .NET Development
root.content:
The .NET Ecosystem

Explore the modern .NET ecosystem for building a wide range of applications, from dynamic web UIs with Blazor to cross-platform native apps with .NET MAUI. This learning path covers the core technologies and rendering models that define modern app development.

quiz.question: Which technology allows C# code to run directly in a web browser?

rendering-models.title: Web Rendering Models
rendering-models.content:
Web Rendering Models

Understanding how a web page is rendered is fundamental to web development. Different models offer trade-offs in performance, SEO, and user experience. Click to explore Server-Side Rendering (SSR) vs. Client-Side Rendering (CSR).

blazor.title: .NET Blazor
blazor.content:
.NET Blazor

A powerful framework for building interactive web UIs using C# instead of JavaScript. Blazor offers different hosting models to suit various application needs. Click to learn more.

maui.title: .NET MAUI
maui.content:
.NET MAUI

Multi-platform App UI (MAUI) is a cross-platform framework for creating native mobile and desktop apps with C# and XAML from a single, shared code-base.

wasm.title: WebAssembly (WASM)
wasm.content:
WebAssembly (WASM)

WebAssembly is a binary instruction format for a stack-based virtual machine. It is designed as a portable compilation target for programming languages, enabling deployment on the web for client and server applications. It allows languages like C, C++, and C# to run in the browser at near-native speed, which is the technology that powers Blazor WebAssembly.
